I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the Country Programming Mission in December 2007, the Government of the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide 
policy and advisory technical assistance for a study on improving road safety through the 
application of intelligent transport systems (ITS). The Fact-Finding Mission visited Beijing in 
December  2008  and  reached  agreement  with  the  Government  on  the  impact,  outcome, 
methodology, key activities, cost estimates, financing plan, and implementation arrangements 
for the technical assistance (TA). The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
This TA has also been included in the ADB nonlending program for the PRC for 2009.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Road accidents are a major negative side effect of transport systems. The World Health 
Organization (WHO) estimates that 1.2 million people are killed in road crashes worldwide each 
year and as many as 50 million are injured.2 WHO predicts that these figures will increase by 
about 65% over the next 20 years unless more attention is given to accident prevention. Road 
accident deaths and injuries bring not only a huge economic loss to developing countries, which 
amounts to 1%–2% of Gross National Product (GNP),3 but also disproportionately harm low-
income groups such as pedestrians, and bicycle and motorcycle riders. The majority of road 
traffic casualties are in the 15–44 age group.4 The associated loss of main income earners has 
an adverse effect on standards of living and poverty. 
 
3.  In the PRC, during 2005–2007 over 260,000 people were killed in road accidents and 
over 1.2 million people were injured. Based on 2004 data, the fatality rate per vehicle in the 
PRC is more than 9 times that in the United Kingdom and more than 5 times that in the United 
States. Since the number of motor vehicles in the PRC is expected to rise, the number of 
fatalities will also increase unless effective actions are taken to help the PRC make its roads 
safer. 
 
4.  The  Government  implements  the  following  policies  to  improve  road  safety: 
(i)   enforcement  of  rules  and  greater  awareness  of  road  safety,  (ii)  improving  roads, 
(iii)   improving  the  safety  of  motor  vehicles,  (iv)  improving  traffic  safety  management,  and 
(v)   developing  technology  to  improve  road  safety.  It  recognizes  that  newly  available 
technologies can play an important role in enhancing the impact of these policies. In many 
businesses and governments around the world, the construction and operation of transport 
systems  is  being  transformed  by  computers,  sensors,  and  communications  technology—
collectively  called  information  technology  (IT).  ITS  is  the  application  of  IT  to  surface 
transportation. ITS provides the ability to gather, organize, analyze, use, and share information 
about transport systems; and to control the systems efficiently and safely. Since most accidents 
are caused by human error or violation of traffic rules, the application of new technology has 
great potential for reducing accidents through a combination of monitoring driving behavior, 
giving warnings to drivers to change their behavior, and controlling transport systems.

5.  The Ministry of Communications5 (MOC) started research and development on ITS in 
the 1990s and developed the ITS strategic program. In the past decade, MOC in cooperation 
with related organizations began deploying ITS applications such as electronic toll collection 
and weather information service. The 11th Five Year Plan for Science and Technology (2006–
2010)  emphasizes  the  utilization  of  ITS  to  improve  transport  systems,  specifically  in  the 
following three fields: (i) to relieve congestion and increase the capacity of the transportation 
system;  (ii)  to  promote  integration  of  the  electronic  information  network  to  maximize  the 
efficiency,  safety,  and  utilization  of  infrastructure;  and  (iii)  to  minimize  the  probability  and 
severity of collisions and reduce accident losses. In accordance with this plan, the following ITS 
technologies were introduced in the public sector in the PRC in recent years: (i) a traffic control 
system to alleviate traffic congestion in Beijing, particularly during the 2008 Olympic Games; 
(ii) a traffic information system that provides travelers with traffic information via internet and 
electric boards in Beijing and Shanghai; and (iii) electronic toll collection on about 4,000 km of 
expressways by 2008.  
 
6.  While the 11th Five Year Plan for Science and Technology emphasized utilizing ITS for 
road safety, implementation is still very limited. The Government is focusing on the following 
four aspects, which are closely related to important areas of its road safety policy: (i) human 
behavior,  (ii)  vehicle  safety,  (iii)  commercial  vehicle  management,  and  (iv)  infrastructure. 
However, there is no policy or guidance for effectively utilizing ITS to improve road safety. On 
the other hand, some ITS technologies have been introduced in the transport industry to control 
driving records for commercial reasons. These technologies have potential for improving road 
safety since they help to reduce excessive working hours and violations of the speed limit by 
monitoring driving behavior and helping to change behavior. To realize the full benefits of these 
technologies, government guidance and standards are needed. Some technologies also have 
potential  for  improving  road  safety  by  providing  accident  information  that  can  be  used  to 
improve road infrastructure at locations where many accidents occur. Such technologies will 
help to decrease fatalities and injuries among pedestrians and non-motorized transport users, 
who tend to be predominantly from low-income groups. 
 
7.  Many developed countries have already recognized the potential of ITS to reduce road 
accidents.  The  European  Commission  deployed  the  “e-Safety”  program  in  2002,  the 
Government of the United States deployed “Vehicle Infrastructure Integration” in 2003 and 
“Intelligent  Vehicle  Initiative”  in  1998,  and  the  Government  of  Japan  deployed  “Advanced 
Cruise-Assist  Highway  Systems”  in  1996  and  “Advanced  Safety  Vehicle”  in  1991.  The 
Government of Japan also promotes ITS projects for commercial vehicle management. In line 
with the actions taken by foreign governments, the Government of the PRC recognizes the 
importance of establishing an effective ITS program for road safety, taking lessons learned from 
other countries into consideration. It is timely to study ITS policies and guidelines for road 
safety, since the application of ITS is expanding to new areas such as commercial vehicle 
management, and the price of IT continues to fall. 
 
8.  The Government has given high priority to road safety in the 11th Five-Year Plan (2006–
2010). Consistent with the plan and aligned with ADB’s country partnership strategy for the 
PRC,6 the proposed TA will aim to assist the Government in formulating policies and guidelines 
to improve road safety through the application of ITS and recommending promising projects to 
implement in future.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The TA aims to contribute to safe and efficient road transport by introducing ITS in the 
PRC.  The  outcome  of  the  TA  will  include  policy  recommendations,  guidelines,  and 
recommendations for ITS projects provided for the consideration of the national Government 
and provincial governments. The output of the TA will be a study which includes (i) policy 
recommendations for the application of ITS, (ii) guidelines on the application of ITS, (iii) several 
recommended ITS projects to improve road safety, and (iv) a policy note summarizing best 
practices for dissemination to high-level policy makers.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  To achieve the outputs of the TA, the consultants will (i) review literature on road safety 
and ITS in the PRC and other countries, including reviewing lessons learned from relevant 
projects; (ii) review best practices in the application of ITS for road safety in the PRC and other 
countries; (iii) conduct three case studies in provinces or cities in the PRC; and (iv) host 
workshops to consult stakeholders. The case studies will be used as the basis for formulating 
ITS policy recommendations and guidelines at a national level by (i) identifying major types of 
accidents and their causes in the case study areas, (ii) identifying the rationale for utilizing ITS 
compared with other road safety measures, and (iii) proposing future ITS projects and policies 
for the use of ITS for road safety. 
 
11.  International and national consultants will be engaged to help the Ministry of Transport 
(MOT) carry out the TA. The consultants will maintain close working relations with MOT and 
ADB,  and  will  regularly  discuss  progress  and  findings.  The  TA  will  involve  (i)  fieldwork, 
(ii) gathering national and international experiences, (iii) analytical research, (iv) consultations 
with the national Government and provincial governments responsible for road transport and 
other stakeholders, and (v) training for building the capacity of government staff. To develop 
capacity,  the  consultants  will  identify  suitable  overseas  training  opportunities  and  arrange 
overseas training to learn from international experience and best practices of ITS road safety 
projects. 
 
12.  With the assistance of the consultants, MOT will conduct workshops to consult with 
stakeholders  and  disseminate  the  TA  findings.  MOT  will  liaise  with  government  agencies 
concerned and stakeholders. The workshops will be held at the inception, interim, and draft final 
report stages. The inception and draft final report workshops will be held in Beijing, and the 
workshops at the interim report stage will be held in each case study area. MOT will provide the 
consultants with all relevant materials, recent studies, and reports required for conducting the 
TA. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $625,000 equivalent. ADB’s TA funding program 
(Technical Assistance Special Fund-others) will finance the TA on a grant basis in the amount of 
$500,000. MOT will finance the remaining $125,000 equivalent, which will be used to cover 
counterpart staff, office space, furniture, and other support services. The detailed cost estimates 
and financing plan are in Appendix 2.

4    
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  MOT will be the Executing Agency for the TA and will be responsible for guiding and 
supervising  the  TA  activities  and  for  coordination  with  relevant  government  agencies  and 
organizations, including provincial and city governments. MOT will (i) ensure the cooperation of 
government agencies and organizations concerned, including provincial and city governments, 
in case studies; and (ii) provide guidance and assistance to consultants to implement the TA. 
MOT will assign appropriate counterpart staff to assist the consultants, and form a project 
 
steering committee to guide and support the TA. This committee will be chaired by the deputy 
director general of the Comprehensive Planning Department of MOT. It will include senior 
officials from the Comprehensive Planning Department, Highway Administration Department, 
and  relevant  officers  of  the  Ministry  of  Finance  and  other  agencies  concerned.  Tripartite 
meetings  involving  ADB  staff,  MOT,  and  consultants  will  be  held  to  provide  guidance  to 
consultants and review their reports. The consultants will submit reports to ADB and MOT as 
scheduled in the design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). All reports by the consultants 
will be written in English and translated into Chinese. 
 
15.  The consultants will be engaged by ADB through a national consulting firm associated 
with an international firm, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2007, as amended from time to time) on the basis of the quality of the proposal (90%) and the 
cost (10%) of the services to be provided using the simplified technical proposal procedures. 
The 90:10 weighting is considered appropriate because the TA is an advanced multidisciplinary 
assignment that requires creativity and a high level of expertise in advanced technologies and 
their application, and the quality of the consulting services will have a significant impact on the 
effectiveness of the TA. The TA will require about 7 person-months of international and about 
30  person-months  of  national  consulting  services  to  carry  out  the  terms  of  reference 
(Appendix 3). The international consultant will have expertise and experience in the fields of 
road  safety  and  ITS.  The  national  consultants  will  have  expertise  and  experience  in  the 
following fields: (i) road safety, (ii) ITS, (iii) commercial vehicle management, and (iv) transport 
regulation  and  standards.  Disbursement  will  be  undertaken  in  line  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook.7 The  TA  will  be  implemented  over  11  months  from 
August 2009 to June 2010.  
 
16.   MOT will provide a suitably furnished office with utilities and telecommunication access, 
materials, maps, data, and documents required by the TA; and will cover the cost of utilities for 
the consultants, counterpart professional staff, and support staff. TA equipment will be procured 
by the consultants in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from 
time to time) and transferred to MOT upon completion of the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Improving Road Safety through the 
Application of Intelligent Transport Systems, and hereby reports the action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
1.  The  consultants  will  perform  their  tasks  in  close  consultation  with  the  Ministry  of 
Transport (MOT), other national government agencies, and provincial governments to ensure 
full acceptance of the outcome of the technical assistance (TA). The TA will require 37.0 
person-months of consulting services (7.0 person-months international and 30.0 person-months 
national) over 11 months, including fieldwork. The consultants should have extensive consulting 
skills and experience in the fields of (i) road safety (2.5 person-months international, 9.0 person-
months national); (ii) intelligent transport systems (ITS) (4.5 person-months international, 11.0 
person-months national); (iii) commercial vehicle management (6.0 person-months national); 
and (iv) transport regulation and standards (4.0 person-months national).  
2.  The consultants must propose their own staffing schedule in the technical proposal, 
demonstrating a well-planned and balanced deployment of the time of each team member to 
meet the TA’s objectives. The assignment requires a strong commitment from the team leader, 
deputy team leader, and team members. 
3.  A national ITS specialist will be the team leader. The team leader must have extensive 
knowledge of ITS, with over 15 years of work experience in relevant fields. The team leader will 
(i) have overall responsibility for effective and timely implementation of the TA; (ii) foster close 
coordination between international and national consultants and coordinate with the Executing 
Agency (EA), other related government agencies, the Asian Development Bank (ADB), and 
other international organizations; and (iii) report progress to the EA and ADB in a timely manner, 
and submit high-quality reports. The transport regulation and standards specialist must have a 
legal background and will be preferably familiar with road accident cases. 
4.  An international consultant will be the deputy team leader. The international consultant 
will cover road safety and ITS, and must have extensive knowledge of ITS road safety projects 
including commercial vehicle management in developed countries. The deputy team leader will 
(i) work closely with the team leader to establish and maintain good coordination with the EA, 
other related government agencies, ADB, and other international organizations; (ii) assist the 
team leader in reporting progress periodically and submitting reports to the EA and ADB; and 
(iii) be responsible for ensuring the high quality of the English versions of the inception, interim, 
draft final, final, and progress reports.  
B.  Consultants 
5.  The  time  estimated  to  complete  the  TA  is  from  August  2009  to  June  2010.  The 
consultants shall commerce work within 15 calendar days of their contract’s effective date. 
 
1.  Road Safety (2.5 person-months international and 9.0 person-months national) 
 
6.  The consultants will undertake the following tasks. 
(i)  Review the literature on road safety in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) and 
other countries. The tasks include, but will not be limited to, reviewing (a) the 
overall trend and characteristics of road accidents with international comparison 
with those of other countries, (b) the costs of road accidents, (c) the major type of 
accidents and the causes, (d) key issues and problems, (e) road safety strategies

Appendix 3  9  
and policies, (f) lessons learned from recent road safety projects including ADB-
supported road safety projects, and (g) recommendations and suggestions. 
(ii)  Review best practices in the PRC and other countries such as the United States, 
Japan, and European countries on the application of ITS for road safety. The 
tasks include, but will not be limited to, reviewing (a) the trend and characteristics 
of road accidents concerning best practices, and (b) the rationale for adopting 
ITS technologies to improve road safety. 
(iii)  Carry out three case studies in provinces or cities in the PRC through field study. 
The tasks include, but will not be limited to (a) analyzing the current status and 
issues, (b) analyzing the characteristics of road accidents by examining accident 
data and other available methods, (c) evaluating ongoing road safety projects, 
and (d) identifying the rationale for utilizing ITS. 
(iv)  Propose  policy  recommendations  for  the  application  of  ITS  to  improve  road 
safety. The tasks include, but will not be limited to (a) determining the rationale 
for utilizing ITS technologies, including how ITS would influence drivers and 
affect driving behavior; and (b) policy recommendations at national and local 
levels. 
(v)  Formulate  guidelines  on  the  application  of  ITS  to  improve  road  safety  in 
coordination with key stakeholders.  
(vi)  Propose ITS projects to improve road safety in the case study provinces or cities. 
The  tasks  include,  but  will  not  be  limited  to  proposing  the  rationale  for  the 
projects, taking cost-effectiveness into consideration. 
(vii)  Formulate  a  short  policy  note  summarizing  best  practices,  which  will  be 
disseminated to high-level policy makers, particularly in the field of road safety. 
 
2.  Intelligent  Transport  Systems  (4.5  person-months  international  and  11.0 
person-months national) 
7.  The consultants will undertake the following tasks. 
(i)  Review the literature on ITS in the PRC and other countries, with a strong 
emphasis on road safety. The tasks include, but will not be limited to, reviewing 
(a)  the  definition  of  ITS;  (b)  the  rationale  of  utilizing  ITS  technologies;                 
(c)  available  technology  and  development  trends;  (d)  strategies,  policies, 
architecture, and deployment both in the public and the private sector; (e) key 
issues and problems; (f) costs and benefits; (g) lessons learned from recent ITS 
projects; and (h) recommendations and suggestions. 
(ii)  Review best practices in the PRC and other countries such as the United States, 
Japan, and European countries on the application of ITS for road safety. The 
tasks  include,  but  will  not  be  limited  to,  reviewing  (a)  the  rationale  for  ITS 
projects;  (b)  policies,  strategies,  architecture,  and  institutional  framework  for 
processing and implementation; (c) the costs and benefits of ITS projects; and 
(d) methods of gaining acceptance from the public. 
(iii)  Carry out three case studies in provinces or cities in the PRC through field study. 
The tasks include, but will not be limited to (a) evaluating the effectiveness of 
ongoing ITS road safety projects, including how ITS affected driver and non-
driver safety; (b) analyzing the rationale of utilizing ITS technologies, including 
how ITS influenced drivers and affected driving behavior; and (c) identifying the 
possible application of ITS to road safety by classifying short-, medium-, and 
long-term application, taking into consideration the development trends on ITS 
technologies.

(iv)  Propose  policy  recommendations  for  the  application  of  ITS  to  improve  road 
safety. The tasks include, but will not be limited to (a) developing a road map for 
utilizing ITS technologies, taking into consideration both the causes of major type 
of  accidents  and  the  development  trends  on  ITS  technologies;  (b)  policy 
recommendations at national and local levels; (c) policy instruments to realize 
these  recommendations;  (d) an institutional  framework  to  involve  all 
stakeholders; and (e) the methods of gaining public acceptance in an effective 
way. 
(v)  Formulate  guidelines  on  the  application  of  ITS  to  improve  road  safety  in 
coordination with key stakeholders. The guidelines will include, but will not be 
limited to (a) recommendations to the transport industry, (b) recommendations to 
the motor vehicle manufacturing industry, and (c) recommendations to motor 
vehicle users. 
(vi)  Propose ITS projects to improve road safety in the case study provinces or cities. 
The tasks include, but will not be limited to, proposing (a) the scope and the 
outline  of  projects,  (b)  an  institutional  framework  for  processing  and 
implementation, (c) estimates of costs and benefits, (d) the role of the public 
sector, (e) risks and limitations of the projects, and (f) the way to gain acceptance 
by the public. 
(vii)  Formulate  a  short  policy  note  summarizing  best  practices,  which  will  be 
disseminated to high-level policy makers. The policy note should be concise; 
include figures, charts, and pictures; and be highly persuasive in presenting the 
case for investing in ITS to improve road safety. 
 
3.  Commercial Vehicle Management (6.0 person-months national) 
8  The consultant will undertake the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Review the literature on road safety and ITS in the field of commercial vehicle 
management in the PRC and other countries. The tasks include, but will not be 
limited to, reviewing (a) characteristics and root causes of road accidents caused 
by commercial vehicles, (b) measures taken by governments and the transport 
industry to prevent road accidents, (c) available ITS technologies, and (d) the 
application of ITS to road safety. 
(ii)  Review best practices in the PRC and other countries such as the United States, 
Japan, and European countries on the application of ITS for road safety in the 
field  of  commercial  vehicle  management.  The  tasks  include,  but  will  not  be 
limited to, reviewing (a) the rationale for ITS projects; (b) costs and benefits of 
ITS projects; and (c) policies, strategies, architecture, and institutional framework 
for processing and implementation of ITS projects. 
(iii)  Carry out three case studies in provinces or cities in the PRC through field study. 
The  tasks  include,  but  will  not  be  limited  to  (a)  collecting  quantitative  and 
qualitative data; (b) evaluating the effectiveness of ongoing projects, including 
costs and benefits; and (c) reviewing lessons learned from the projects. 
(iv)  Propose  policy  recommendations  for  the  application  of  ITS  to  improve  road 
safety, particularly in the field of commercial vehicle management. 
(v)  Formulate guidelines on the application of ITS to improve road safety, particularly 
in the field of commercial vehicle management. 
(vi)  Propose ITS projects to improve road safety in the case study provinces or cities, 
particularly in the field of commercial vehicle management.

Appendix 3  11  
4.  Transport Regulation and Standards (4.0 person-months national) 
9.  The consultant will undertake the following tasks. 
 
(i)  Review the literature on laws on road safety and regulation and standards of ITS 
in the PRC and other countries. The tasks include, but will not be limited to, 
reviewing  (a)  the  current  status  of  laws  on  road  safety  and  regulation  and 
standards of ITS, (b) international standards and harmonization activities of ITS, 
and (c) legal issues regarding introducing ITS for road safety. 
(ii)  Review best practices in ITS road safety projects in the PRC and other countries, 
from the viewpoint of regulation and standards. The tasks include, but will not be 
limited  to,  reviewing  (a)  regulations  concerning  ITS  road  safety  projects; 
(b) standards  of  utilized  ITS;  and  (c)  legal  provision  for  the  usage  of  ITS, 
including legal responsibilities and compensation in case of accidents induced by 
ITS. 
(iii)  Carry out case studies in three provinces or cities in the PRC through field study. 
The tasks include, but will not be limited to, reviewing (a) regulations concerning 
ITS road safety projects; (b) standards of utilized ITS; and (c) legal provision for 
the usage of ITS, including legal responsibilities and compensation in case of 
accidents induced by ITS. 
(iv)  Propose  policy  recommendations  for  the  application  of  ITS  to  improve  road 
safety, particularly from the viewpoint of regulation and standards. The tasks 
include, but will not be limited to, proposing (a) a regulatory framework at national 
and  local  levels;  (b)  legal  provision  for  the  usage  of  ITS,  including  legal 
responsibilities  and  compensation  in  case  of  accidents  induced  by  ITS;  and 
(c) international harmonization of standards. 
(v)  Formulate guidelines on the application of ITS to improve road safety, particularly 
from the viewpoint of regulation and standards.  
(vi)  Propose ITS projects to improve road safety in the case study provinces or cities, 
particularly from the viewpoint of regulation and standards. 
 
C.  Reporting and Workshops  
10.  The consultants will submit the following reports to ADB and MOT: 
(i)  Lists  of  (a)  sources  of  information;  (b)  related  regulations;  (c)  related 
organizations and contact persons; (d) candidates for best practices in the PRC 
and other countries, and case study provinces or cities; (e) key relevant policy 
papers and research papers translated into English available so far; and (f) the 
outline of the final report (month 1). 
(ii)  Literature  reviews,  issues  identified  so  far,  key  relevant  policy  papers,  and 
research papers translated into English (month 2). 
(iii)  An  inception  report,  including  literature  review,  methodology,  and  proposed 
international training programs (month 2). 
(iv)  A report on the first workshop (month 3). 
(v)  Case studies carried out so far (month 4). 
(vi)  An interim report summarizing all work performed (month 5).  
(vii)  A report on workshops in case study areas (month 6). 
(viii)  Case and best practice studies carried out so far (month 7) 
(ix)  Case studies, best practices, and the outline of the possible future projects in the 
case study areas (month 8)

Appendix 3  12  
(x)  A  comprehensive  draft  final  report  on  all  aspects  of  the  TA,  including  an 
executive summary and the policy note. The comments from MOT and ADB will 
be issued to consultants no later than 4 weeks after receipt of the draft final 
report (month 9). 
(xi)  A report on the final workshop (month 10). 
(xii)  A comprehensive final report on all aspects of the TA within 4 weeks of receiving 
all comments from MOT and ADB, taking into account the results and feedback 
from the final workshop (month 11). 
(xiii)  The policy note produced to a standard ready for publication (month 11). 
(xiv)  The printed policy note (month 12). 
 
11.  All reports will be written in English and translated into Chinese. Five copies of the 
inception report, interim report, and draft final report (in English) will be submitted to ADB; and 
5 copies (in both Chinese and English) to MOT. Five copies of the final report (in English) will be 
submitted to ADB and 10 copies (in both Chinese and English) to MOT. Three hundred copies 
of the policy note (in English) will be submitted to ADB and 500 copies (in both Chinese and 
English) to MOT. Three copies of other progress reports (in English) will be submitted to ADB 
and 5 copies (in both Chinese and English) to MOT. The consultants will report on progress and 
key findings to the project steering committee. ADB staff will participate in the tripartite meetings 
and workshops.  
12.  The consultants will assist the EA in carrying out the following workshops, at which the 
consultants will present key findings. 
(i)  The first 1-day workshop to be held in Beijing after submission of the inception 
report to (a) consult stakeholders, (b) ensure that key issues on the application of 
ITS to improve road safety are clearly understood, and (c) discuss the focus of 
policy recommendations and recommended projects (month 2). 
(ii)  Workshops to be held in each of the case study areas to (a) consult stakeholders 
at  the  local  level,  (b)  discuss  the  rationale  of  utilizing  ITS  for  road  safety, 
(c) discuss the results of case studies so far, and (d) discuss the possible future 
application (months 5–6).   
(iii)  The final 1-day national workshop will be held in Beijing after submission of the 
draft final report to (a) ensure that the draft final report is clearly understood to 
exchange  ideas;  (b)  discuss  recommended  policies,  guidelines,  and 
recommended  projects;  (c)  discuss  future  projects;  and  (d)  disseminate  the 
findings and raise public awareness. The final workshop should be open to the 
public (month 9).
